title: Upcoming interactive workshop at the National Open Science Festival: Stimulating Data (Re)Use
text:
Researchers routinely use insights from previous work – but typically they use publications more often and more intensively than the underlying data. While significant efforts have been invested in ensuring the production of FAIR data, an equally critical aspect - stimulating the reuse of data - remains relatively underexplored. This interactive workshop aims to address this gap by engaging participants in discussions and activities that will uncover barriers to data reuse and develop actionable strategies to enhance the consumption of FAIR research data among researchers.
During this workshop, research support staff, researchers, funders, policy makers and others will be working collaboratively on these objectives: - Identifying barriers and exploring motivators: taking into account differences between research domains, participants will identify common obstacles that hinder the (re)use of FAIR data, including technical, cultural, and policy-related challenges. We will also explore what motivates researchers to reuse data, examining successful case studies and reviewing results from studies on this topic. - Developing strategies: participants will collaborate to develop practical strategies and recommendations to promote the (re)use of FAIR data. - Action plan: participants will be provided with a template to create an action plan tailored to their research domains or research communities, aiming to foster a culture of data reuse. - Continued collaboration and community development: participants will be invited to share their action plans in a common online space and collaborate in a newly formed community on stimulating data (re)use.
Organized by: Hugo Quené, Aleid de Jong, Jacques Flores, Jonathan de Bruin, and Coosje Veldkamp, Utrecht University The workshop will be held at the Netherlands National Open Science Festival at Maastricht University on October 22, 2024.

title: RDS Hay Day
text: On September 16, 2024, the Research Data Services department at Utrecht University Library gathered together at the University Science Park to begin the task of plotting out our annual activities.

title: Newsletter RDM Support - June 2024
text:
Ron Scholten received the Research Support Champion Award 2024 for his outstanding work on the YOUth project as well as for his work on Yoda. The jury describes Ron Scholten as pivotal in the YOUth study, where he ensures the storage, validation, and careful provision of sensitive data about young children. Read more about the outstanding work of Ron.



Rens van der Schoot received a Vici-grant, the prestigious NWO grant to expand his work on ASReview. Rens van de Schoot emphasises that this award is team science in optima forma. “ITS and the university library should also be recognised in this: without them, this project would be nowhere.” Read more about the team effort leading to the grant.

title: Newsletter RDM Support - June 2024
text:
How to be FAIR

Latest FAIR Story About Cognitive Mapping Published
In this interview, Femke van Esch tells us about Cognitive Mapping, a method for mapping people’s beliefs and reasoning. The previously complicated method was made more user-friendly by developing the new software CognitiveMapr for which she received a grant from the FAIR Research IT Innovation Fund. There are more projects that received a grant from the fund, such as Kees Klein Goldewijk’s HYDE database. Learn more about cognitive mapping.


FAIR Cheat Sheets have been Published
Finding your way around the FAIR principles may prove to be a little daunting. That is why science historian and philosopher Susanna Bloem made grateful use of the FAIR Cheatsheets developed by experts from the Utrecht University Open Science Programme and RDM Support in consultation with researchers from several faculties. Read all about how she used this useful checklist to see if her data and code adhered to the FAIR principles. Learn more about FAIR Cheat Sheets

title: Newsletter RDM Support - June 2024
text:
As Good as New

Data Odyssey project at Geo
Remember the times of the floppy disks? Zip drives? CD-ROMS? It seems ages ago, but the data on these carriers are still valuable. The Geo Data Team managed to retrieve the data from these outdated data carriers and opened up the research data that Martin Wassen had collected for over four decades. Watch datasteward Garrett Speed present the project here. Read more about the Data Odyssey Project.


Faculty Support Teams
We continuously update our website. Last time you received the newsletter, we mentioned we updated all the guides, now we’ve added information about the faculty support teams. We always welcome input on info.rdm@uu.nl. The upcoming period we will be working on FAQ’s for Yoda.

title: Newsletter RDM Support - June 2024
text:
Meet Leo!

New DMP Module Now Available 24/7 Online
From now on you can learn all there is to know about writing your Data Management Plan whenever and wherever you want. In this e-learning module you will master all the basic concepts you need to write a good plan in about 1.5 hours with the help of Leonardo. Get started with your DMP now!

title: Programming Café, September 2024
text:
Event Time and date: 12 September 2024 - 15 to 17hr Location: Bucheliuszaal 6.18, Universiteitsbibliotheek (Utrecht Science Park)
Do you want to improve your programming skills, meet colleagues interested in coding, or ask questions related to research software? Pick up your laptop and come to the Programming Café!
In this monthly meet-up, we will share knowledge about programming through short presentations, work on software projects, and help each other with challenges in working with code and data.
This month’s theme: Introducing iBridges
Do you already use Yoda to store your data? Would you like to find out what else the system can do?
In this talk, we will demonstrate how to leverage the full potential of Yoda through a new tool box called iBridges. iBridges consists of a python library to easily program against data, a command line tool for streamlined uploading and downloading of data, and a graphical user interface to enhance the experience of using Yoda. We will present a compute workflow that uses data in Yoda, generates results, and levels them with data. Subsequently, the results can be found by a non-programming user employing the GUI and downloading the results of the compute workflow. Join us to explore the functionality hidden inside of Yoda.
What to expect
During the Programming Café, you can work on your own project and share knowledge in a community setting. You can also bring your programming questions, bugs, and problems to discuss or resolve with members of Information Technology Support, Research Data Services, and researchers attending the café. In addition, each Programming Café will have a special theme. This is typically a short presentation or demonstration of (maximum) half an hour. We are always looking for suggestions on themes and people who want to present something. Don’t hesitate to send an email to info.rdm@uu.nl if you want to provide a suggestion or give a presentation!
Who can attend
Everyone is welcome at the Programming Café! You can be of any skill level and at any stage in working with your code and data. While many attendees will be R or Python users, people interested in other programming languages and software are invited as well.
Full information can be found at (uu.nl/rdm)[https://www.uu.nl/en/events/programming-cafe-12-september-2024]

title: Upcoming Workshop at the National Open Science Festival with RDS and UDCC: Building the Commons
text:
Upcoming Workshop: Building the Commons
The implementation of Open Science across the Netherlands is beginning to reorient the way people at knowledge organisations structure their work. Institutions are affirming these changes by reimaging programs for Recognition & Reward and developing innovative networks such as DCCs (Digital Competence Centers). By exploring these modes of support and collaboration across the Netherlands, this interactive session will co-design structures that facilitate community, valorisation, and care as intrinsic to science.
The workshop “Building the Commons: How Open Science and DCCs Bring About New Ways of Working” will be divided into three parts. The initial presentation will establish a shared foundation for ideas around open and networked modes of knowledge production, introducing the concept of the commons. The second section will showcase a series of spaces already beginning to enact this type of cooperation within and among organisations in the Netherlands, including Utrecht DCC, VU Art Science, the Dutch Open Science Communities, and the national TDCC. Finally, participants will engage in a collective exercise to design common networks across their communities. The session is intended for people working in research and research support who are interested in the connections and infrastructure that generate Open Science.
During this session, we will assert that the present moment in the Netherlands is an extraordinary opportunity to build such knowledge commons due to the national commitment to Open Science and the unique affiliations among present knowledge workers. We seek to build upon this collaborative spirit to render our work more inclusive, engaged, diverse, equitable, and meaningful. People attending this session will gain insight into projects that rethink cooperation as well as a framework and lexicon to render those types of efforts more visible and resilient. The output will be designs and resources that help people participate in and replicate open and networked forms of knowledge production.
Organized by: Coosje Veldkamp, Utrecht University Anna van ’t Veer, OSC-NL Martine de Vos, Utrecht University Nicole Emmenegger, TDCC–SSH Dan Rudmann, Utrecht University Lieke de Boer, Netherlands eScience Center Lena Karvovskaya, Vrije Universiteit Lilli van Wielink, Utrecht University
The workshop will be held at the Netherlands National Open Science Festival at Maastricht University on October 22, 2024.
